IS GIVEN $25
GOLD PIECE
Winning Article Published In
News-Letter November
10, 1931

"A GEOLOGIST VIEWS
AFRICA,'' IS TITLE

-

Manes Is Now Engaged In
Geological Work In
Africa
"A Geo-logist Views Africa,"
an article written by 0. B. Manes,
Jr., a graduate student in geology,
and published in the News-Letter
of November 10, 1931, was judged
the winner of the $25 gold piece
given annually for the best article
printed in the campus paper.
Grad Wins

For the first time since the
award has been given by Dr.
Jacob H. Hollander, professor of
political economy, a graduate student has won the prize. \II/hen
the judges finally selected the
winning article Saturday afternoon Dr. Hollander was asked
whell1er a graduate student wa·s
eligible for the award. It is
understood that he replied that
inasmuch as he has never set
down specific regulations concerning the contest, he had no
personal objections to giving the
$25 gold piece to Manes.
Five Judges

Those faculty members, all of
the department of English, who
judged contributions to the News
Letter were Dr. L. W. Miles, S
B. Ewing, C. P. Lyons, S. W
Stevenson, and G. H. Harper. In
choosing the best article, each
judge chose what he regarded as
the best contribution in a certain
number of issues of the paper
which he was given to read. The
five articles thus chosen were
read by every judge and the final
selection made from the "semifinal" choices.
In Africa Now

Manes left for Angola, in
Portugese West Africa, on April
29, it was learned yesterday
There he is doing geologic and
topographic work

PROF. WOOD LECTURES
0N "FLU 0RES CE NS E"
Professor Of Experimental Physics Shows Effects Caused By
Ultra Violet
Dr. R. vV. Wood, Professor of
Experimental Physics, lectured
on Fluorescence, last Friday, before members of the faculty of
the Physics and Chemistry departments.
He showed many spectacular
effects, especially the fluorescence caused by ultra violet light
Professor \i'l/ood is a leading international authority in this subject, much of which has been discovered by the Homewood Physicist himself.
He is the author of the article
on Fluorescence in the Encyclopedia Britannica.

Friends Of The
Library

A tea was held in Gilman Hall
.last Sunday, May 22, by the Friends
of the Library at which opportunity
was afforded to meet Mr. Philip
Hofer, curator of the Rare Book
and Manuscript Division of the
New York Public Library.
Mr. Hofer exhibited some rare
manuscripts and gave an informal
talk on the Spenser Bequest and
other treasures that are in his care.

WILL SWING UNDER
WAY ON JUNE 8
Tickets For Entire Week
To Sell For
$12.50
Members of the June Week committee, headed by Walter Kneip,
yesterday appealed for a better support of the annual event. .Final
arrangements have been made for
the Week, which swings under way
on \i\Tednesday, June 8.
Bud Cadori At Club Party

Bud Cadori's orchestra and the
Colgan Sisters will appear at the
Night Club Party, which opens the
activties, to be held at the L'Hirondelle Club from 10 P. M. to 2 A. M.
Of this initial event of June Week,
the committee .says that "smooth
music will be the order of the evening and real entertainment will be
furnished."
On the following day, June 9,
Mago~Vista will be the scene of the
beach party, 2 P. M. to midnight,
where there'll be swimming, boating, canoeing, a picnic supper and
dancing with music by Jules Penrose's orchestra. "For those to
whom dancing is not entertaining
enough, a special moon will be
furnished," the committee announces.

Social and Natural Science
Books Are Announced
COMPREHENSIVE TO
BE GIVEN NEXT YEAR
All Juniors And Sophs Required To Take
Exams
Announcements of the revised
reading lists of the Social Science
and Natural Science groups have
been released by the Office of the
Dean.
Under the new plan, which was
recently announced, the upper classmen are required to have a general
knowledge of the group in which
they are studying. It is not necessary, however, to take courses to
obtain this general knowledge. The
survey of an entire group may be
made by reading the books in the
following lists.
List Revised

The Social Science reading list
has been revised, and the following
books are advised as those which
contain the desi;·~d kno~ledge ·.in
its best form.
Recommended general reading:
Alexander Gray: Development of
Econorn.dc Doctrine.
Delisle Burns: Political Ideals.
C. A. Beard: Economic Basis of
Politics. The Constitution of
the United States.
P. T. Moon: Imperialism and
World Politics.
W. H. Chamberlin: Soviet Russia.
W. J. Ashley: Economic Organi• zation of England.
P. Vidal de la Blaehe: Principles
of Human Geo-graphy.
M. R. Cohen: Reason and Nature.
(pp. 333-368).
G. L. Burr: The Freedom of History in The American Historical Review, vol. 22, pp. 253271.

The student is urged to read the
following classics of social science
because of the suggestiveness of
the thought. His knowledge of
their content will not be tested by
examination.

IANNONE, FRESHMAN,
IS AWARDED CUP
IN SPEAKING CONTEST
Is The Third Winner Of
Thom Prize, Given
Annually
WINNER BEATS NINE
OTHER CONTESTANTS
"How To Dispense Million
Dollars Unselfishly" Is
Topic
A. B. Iannone, a freshman, was
declared winner of the Thom Cup,
an award given annually by ).frs.
H. R. M. Thom, of Baltimore, to
the best extemporaneous speaker.
Iannone was one or ten contestants who competed in Levering Hall
last Thursday. The topic for each
entrant was: "An Unexpected
Legacy of One Million Dollars has
gone to you with the only stipulation that you must use it as unselfishly as possible. What will you
do with it?" The speakers were
judged on the basis of 331/a % on
subject matter and thought; 331/a %
on platform bearing, personality,
and appearance; and 331/a % on diction, vocabulary, grammar, grace of
speech, enunciation.
Iannone, the final speaker of the
group, expressed the opinion that
a part of the money should be
given to the Hopkins; that another
part should be used to educate some
boys who warranted help but lacked the financial means ; and that the
rest should be given for the building of an annex to a new high
school in Orange, New Jersey,
which, he asserted, "is a great little
school."

From Mine Fields Of l(entucky inwinner,
were, in order of their ap-

Action Taken By Officials Proves Total Absence Of Civil
Rights In Kentucky Territory,, Says
Economy Professor
Recently returned from a trip to
the trouble centers of the Kentucky
mine fields, where he went as a
member of a party under the
auspices of the American Civil
Liberties Union to test the right of
free speech and assemblies, Dr.
Broadus Mitchall was vehement in
his denounciation of affairs there at
the present time.
Although the expedition failed to
gain admittance to their objectiveBell County-he considered it a success as the fact of their being refused entry upheld their contention
that free speech and civil liberties
are not in force in the district at
the present time.

Receiving notice from Walter B.
Smith, county attorney of Bell
county, that they would be treated
as "mad dogs" in the county, the
party proceeded to London, Kentucky, where they applied to Judge
Cochran for an injuction to restrain county officers and others
from interfering with them in their
"lawful errand of testing the constitutional guarantees of free speech
and assemblies." At first stating
that he would either grant the injunction or accompany the party
himself, the judge later refused to
take either course.
(Continued on page 4, column 2)

Armstrong. The contestants were
allowed four minutes to speak, following five minutes of preparation. No one knew the topic until
five minutes before he was to appear, and no one heard any of those
who preceded him, althongh after
finishing his own speech he was allowed to hear the erst.
The cup was presented to Iannone by Dr. C. French, Librarian
of the University, who announced
the name of the winner.
The judges of the contest were
Mr. DeCourcy W. Thom, prominent
lawyer and banker of Baltimore;
Mr. F. F. Birne, of the Baltimore
Evening Sun; and Norman Heaney,
winner of the cup last year. Dan
Miller presided.

Asks Students
For Support

According to a recent statement
from the Olympic Finance Committee, the campaign to raise $1,000
has been far from ·successful.
"Every Hopkins man should be
willing to buy at least one chance
on the raffle of the De Soto automobile," said Kenneth Sharretts
committee chairman. It is by means
of this raffle that the committee expects to raise the required funds.
Sharrets especially urged that
books of tickets be taken to friends
and families outside the University.
An added inducement of a $10
award is offered the student selling
the most tickets, while another $10
will go to the committeeman distributing and selling the greatest
number.

in impressive fashion by a score of
7-3. Bewildered from the very outset, when Turnbull took the initial
faceoff from their All-American
center, the Terps were out played
in every phase of the game until
they found themselves in the second
half, when it was too late.

Jays Tire

Stude proved himself the master
of a ticklish situation. Early in the
second half, after a mad scramble
for the ball, the Jay goalie found
himself confronted by an unguarded Maryland attack man
standing on the crease in the very
act of shooting, only miraculously
quick action enabled the Jay to
check the stick of tHe Terp and save
a sure goal. Undaunted by this
heart-breaking failure to score,
Maryland returned to ring up their
second goal, as Ronkin netted his
first. Unquestionably, the Jays
were tiring fast. Only Turnbull
seemed to retain the fire of the
opening session, as he continued to
best Pugh at the faceoff. An injury
to a Maryland player provided
breathing space for both sides and
Kneip went in for Lang at third
defence for the Jays.
Hopkins was slow to clear the
ball from around their goal and
Maryland succeeded in planting
another in the net. Ronkin was
again the shooter.
Win National Title

Only on two or three occasions
were the Jays able to flash the
brand of lacrosse that they did during the opening period. On these
occasions it was only Fate that prevented additional points from being
included in the total amassed by the
Jays. The closing moments of the
game saw the ball take numerous
trips up and down the field. "Moke"
Merriken was playing a stellar
game on the defence and more than
once was responsible for the ball's
ride toward Maryland's goal.
The victory virtually assures the
Jays of the National and Inter-collegiate Lacrosse titles, and places
them in the favorite's chair to represent the United States in the
coming Olympic games.

"A Geo-logist Views Africa,"
an article written by 0. B. Manes,
Jr., a graduate student in geology,
and published in the News-Letter
of November 10, 1931, was judged
the winner of the $25 gold piece
given annually for the best article
printed in the campus paper.
Grad Wins

For the first time since the
award has been given by Dr.
Jacob H. Hollander, professor of
political economy, a graduate student has won the prize. \II/hen
the judges finally selected the
winning article Saturday afternoon Dr. Hollander was asked
whell1er a graduate student wa·s
eligible for the award. It is
understood that he replied that
inasmuch as he has never set
down specific regulations concerning the contest, he had no
personal objections to giving the
$25 gold piece to Manes.
Five Judges

Those faculty members, all of
the department of English, who
judged contributions to the News
Letter were Dr. L. W. Miles, S
B. Ewing, C. P. Lyons, S. W
Stevenson, and G. H. Harper. In
choosing the best article, each
judge chose what he regarded as
the best contribution in a certain
number of issues of the paper
which he was given to read. The
five articles thus chosen were
read by every judge and the final
selection made from the "semifinal" choices.
In Africa Now

Manes left for Angola, in
Portugese West Africa, on April
29, it was learned yesterday
There he is doing geologic and
topographic work

Professor Of Experimental Physics Shows Effects Caused By

Dr. R. vV. Wood, Professor of
Experimental Physics, lectured
on Fluorescence, last Friday, before members of the faculty of
the Physics and Chemistry departments.
He showed many spectacular
effects, especially the fluorescence caused by ultra violet light
Professor \i'l/ood is a leading international authority in this subject, much of which has been discovered by the Homewood Physicist himself.
He is the author of the article
on Fluorescence in the Encyclopedia Britannica.

of the Library at which opportunity
was afforded to meet Mr. Philip
Hofer, curator of the Rare Book
and Manuscript Division of the
New York Public Library.
Mr. Hofer exhibited some rare
manuscripts and gave an informal
talk on the Spenser Bequest and
other treasures that are in his care.

$12.50
Members of the June Week committee, headed by Walter Kneip,
yesterday appealed for a better support of the annual event. .Final
arrangements have been made for
the Week, which swings under way
on \i\Tednesday, June 8.
Bud Cadori At Club Party

Bud Cadori's orchestra and the
Colgan Sisters will appear at the
Night Club Party, which opens the
activties, to be held at the L'Hirondelle Club from 10 P. M. to 2 A. M.
Of this initial event of June Week,
the committee .says that "smooth
music will be the order of the evening and real entertainment will be
furnished."
On the following day, June 9,
Mago~Vista will be the scene of the
beach party, 2 P. M. to midnight,
where there'll be swimming, boating, canoeing, a picnic supper and
dancing with music by Jules Penrose's orchestra. "For those to
whom dancing is not entertaining
enough, a special moon will be
furnished," the committee announces.

Announcements of the revised
reading lists of the Social Science
and Natural Science groups have
been released by the Office of the
Dean.
Under the new plan, which was
recently announced, the upper classmen are required to have a general
knowledge of the group in which
they are studying. It is not necessary, however, to take courses to
obtain this general knowledge. The
survey of an entire group may be
made by reading the books in the
following lists.
List Revised

has been revised, and the following
books are advised as those which
contain the desi;·~d kno~ledge ·.in
its best form.

the United States.

World Politics.

of Human Geo-graphy.

IANNONE, FRESHMAN,
IS AWARDED CUP
IN SPEAKING CONTEST
Is The Third Winner Of
Thom Prize, Given
Annually
WINNER BEATS NINE
OTHER CONTESTANTS
"How To Dispense Million
Dollars Unselfishly" Is
Topic
A. B. Iannone, a freshman, was
declared winner of the Thom Cup,
an award given annually by ).frs.
H. R. M. Thom, of Baltimore, to
the best extemporaneous speaker.
Iannone was one or ten contestants who competed in Levering Hall
last Thursday. The topic for each
entrant was: "An Unexpected
Legacy of One Million Dollars has
gone to you with the only stipulation that you must use it as unselfishly as possible. What will you
do with it?" The speakers were
judged on the basis of 331/a % on
subject matter and thought; 331/a %
on platform bearing, personality,
and appearance; and 331/a % on diction, vocabulary, grammar, grace of
speech, enunciation.
Iannone, the final speaker of the
group, expressed the opinion that
a part of the money should be
given to the Hopkins; that another
part should be used to educate some
boys who warranted help but lacked the financial means ; and that the
rest should be given for the building of an annex to a new high
school in Orange, New Jersey,
which, he asserted, "is a great little
school."

Action Taken By Officials Proves Total Absence Of Civil
Rights In Kentucky Territory,, Says
Economy Professor
Recently returned from a trip to
the trouble centers of the Kentucky
mine fields, where he went as a
member of a party under the
auspices of the American Civil
Liberties Union to test the right of
free speech and assemblies, Dr.
Broadus Mitchall was vehement in
his denounciation of affairs there at
the present time.
Although the expedition failed to
gain admittance to their objectiveBell County-he considered it a success as the fact of their being refused entry upheld their contention
that free speech and civil liberties
are not in force in the district at
the present time.

Receiving notice from Walter B.
Smith, county attorney of Bell
county, that they would be treated
as "mad dogs" in the county, the
party proceeded to London, Kentucky, where they applied to Judge
Cochran for an injuction to restrain county officers and others
from interfering with them in their
"lawful errand of testing the constitutional guarantees of free speech
and assemblies." At first stating
that he would either grant the injunction or accompany the party
himself, the judge later refused to
take either course.

Asks Students
For Support

According to a recent statement
from the Olympic Finance Committee, the campaign to raise $1,000
has been far from ·successful.
"Every Hopkins man should be
willing to buy at least one chance
on the raffle of the De Soto automobile," said Kenneth Sharretts
committee chairman. It is by means
of this raffle that the committee expects to raise the required funds.
Sharrets especially urged that
books of tickets be taken to friends
and families outside the University.
An added inducement of a $10
award is offered the student selling
the most tickets, while another $10
will go to the committeeman distributing and selling the greatest
number.

Jays Tire

Stude proved himself the master
of a ticklish situation. Early in the
second half, after a mad scramble
for the ball, the Jay goalie found
himself confronted by an unguarded Maryland attack man
standing on the crease in the very
act of shooting, only miraculously
quick action enabled the Jay to
check the stick of tHe Terp and save
a sure goal. Undaunted by this
heart-breaking failure to score,
Maryland returned to ring up their
second goal, as Ronkin netted his
first. Unquestionably, the Jays
were tiring fast. Only Turnbull
seemed to retain the fire of the
opening session, as he continued to
best Pugh at the faceoff. An injury
to a Maryland player provided
breathing space for both sides and
Kneip went in for Lang at third
defence for the Jays.
Hopkins was slow to clear the
ball from around their goal and
Maryland succeeded in planting
another in the net. Ronkin was
again the shooter.
Win National Title

Only on two or three occasions
were the Jays able to flash the
brand of lacrosse that they did during the opening period. On these
occasions it was only Fate that prevented additional points from being
included in the total amassed by the
Jays. The closing moments of the
game saw the ball take numerous
trips up and down the field. "Moke"
Merriken was playing a stellar
game on the defence and more than
once was responsible for the ball's
ride toward Maryland's goal.
The victory virtually assures the
Jays of the National and Inter-collegiate Lacrosse titles, and places
them in the favorite's chair to represent the United States in the
coming Olympic games.

happen nowadays. Hence the United States Air Corps offers some
attractive inducements to you college students for whom it has built
a $10,000,000 institution at San Antonio, Texas, where they teach you
to fly and while you are learning:
Pay you a salary of $75.00 per month. Pay your living expenses.
Supply you (free, of course) with snappy, tailor-made, sky blue
uniforms.
Grant you the social and military privileges of potential officers.
Pay your traveling expenses from your home to the new field at
San Antonio. 700 men are taken in each year. The course requires a
year to complete and includes over 200 hours of solo flying. Those
who stay the full year are commissioned as Lieutenants in the Air
Corps Reserve.
If you don't like the training you may resign at any time. For
example:
Should you stay three months and then resign you will receive
$225.00 cash, your round trip expenses from your home to San
Antonio, and about 50 hours of solo flying.
The service and associations of the Air Corps gives its members
a very real distinction and a very noticeable breadth and poise

information written by men who have been thru the school covers
